channel.title: The Internet Classroom 2010: Lectures
channel.copyright: All "Internet Classroom" materials copyright Â© 2010 Alex Hong, Cynthia Nie, and Sam Pierce.

item.title: More CSS
item.description:
Block vs Inline

  • Inline elements do not start a new line and stay within the flow of a paragraph. They take up only as much space on the page as they need. Examples: a, em, strong, img

  • Block elements are treated like little boxes stacked up on the page. They take up as much horizontal space as they are given, but only as much vertical space as they need. Examples: header elements, p, ul/ol, li, dl, table

Box Model

  • All block elements follow the box model: 2dboxmodel.png

  • margin -> border -> padding -> content

  • The width and height of an element only defines the content itself: it does not include padding/margin/border

  • Alternatively, if it helps you visualize better... 3d box model

IDs/Classes

  • Will help you create more ways of identifying your code, so that you can apply styles to more unique situations

  • IDs can be accessed by using a pound sign (#) and may only be used ONCE in a document. These are especially good for marking off clear sections in your website, like "navigation" or "content" or "header", etc.

  • Classes can be accessed by using a period and can be used repeatedly in a document. Note: Always try to use descendent selectors or IDs before resorting to classes. In many cases, you can access the element you want with the previous two methods. Failure to properly markup your document can result in class abuse.

  • span and div: generic inline and block tags, respectively, for use in conjunction with IDs and classes.

External Stylesheet

To create an external CSS file, open a new Notepad document and save it with a .css extension (remember to switch the "Save As" drop-down to "All Files"). ONLY put CSS in this file, no HTML (like <style>).

Then, in your HTML file, add the following to your <head>:

      <link href="filename.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
item.author: (kass)

item.title: CSS Basics
item.description:
Concepts covered

  • CSS Syntax: selector { property: value; }

  • Descendant selectors

  • Pseudo-selectors

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">

<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">

<head>
  <title>CSS 101</title>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />


<style type="text/css">

body {
  background-image: url("hero.gif");
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
  background-position: bottom right;
}

p {      
  color: DarkViolet;
  font-weight: bold;
}

h1 {
  color: CadetBlue;
  text-decoration: overline underline;
  
  text-align: center;
  font-size: 2em;

  font-family: "Trebuchet MS", Arial, Verdana, sans-serif;

  background-color: #000;
}

ul {
  font-size: 24px;
  font-weight: bold;
}

ol ul {
  color: yellow;
}

em, h2 {
  font-size: 64px;
  color: red;
  font-style: normal;
}

a:link {
  color: yellow;
}

a:visited {
  color: green;
}

a:hover {
  color: blue;
  text-decoration: underline;
}

a:active {
  color: white;
}

a {
  text-decoration: none;
}

</style>

</head>
<body>

<h1>Tired of black and white? Me too!</h1>

<p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis in facilisis sapien. Etiam sit amet sem elit. Integer vitae justo justo, et venenatis ante. Quisque tellus velit, tempor vitae consectetur id, molestie non quam. Aliquam tincidunt, ante et interdum pharetra, quam risus auctor felis, vitae commodo urna dolor eu nunc. Suspendisse ut porta est. </p>

<p>Proin consequat convallis erat, et vehicula nibh pretium non. Nullam a dolor id leo interdum sagittis eu id odio. Maecenas congue enim nec nunc pharetra vel dapibus elit cursus. Vivamus ante elit, vulputate id hendrerit consequat, condimentum a metus. </p>

<p>Mauris porttitor, metus sed imperdiet semper, turpis dolor egestas lorem, tristique porta libero neque sit amet tellus. Praesent tempor luctus libero, vel hendrerit justo commodo gravida. Pellentesque habitant morbi tristique senectus et netus et malesuada fames ac turpis egestas.</p>

<h2>If it's latin, it must be important</h2>

<ol>
<li>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.</li>
<li>Donec sed orci eu massa tempor faucibus id in justo.
<ul>
<li><em>Lorem</em> ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.</li>
<li>Donec sed orci eu massa tempor faucibus id in justo.</li>
<li>Sed tristique massa eget arcu dapibus eu sagittis turpis bibendum.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Sed tristique massa eget arcu dapibus eu sagittis turpis bibendum.</li>
</ol>

<ul>
<li><a href="asdf.html">Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.</a></li>
<li><a href="somewhere.html">Donec sed orci eu massa tempor faucibus id in justo.</a></li>
<li>Sed tristique massa eget arcu dapibus eu sagittis turpis bibendum.</li>
</ul>

</body>
</html>
item.author: (kass)

item.title: XHTML Standards Compliance
item.description:
Standards Compliance Rules

Also found here if you prefer: ~rastley/standards.html

The three things you need in all of your HTML documents. (Note: you still give all your documents a .html extension, despite our use of the term XHTML.)

  • Add a "DOCTYPE" declaration to all your documents.

          <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" 
      "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">

  • Your beginning <html> tag shall henceforth look like this:

          <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en" lang="en">

  • And you must include the following tag within your <head> </head> section:

          <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"/>

XHTML rules (most of which you've already been doing!)

  • Tag contents should always be lowercase.

  • Tags that have attributes defined in them must have quotation marks, either a single or double.

  • All tags must have an accompanying closing tag, even "empty" tags.

  • Nest your tags properly: First In, Last Out as they say. (i.e. <strong><em></em></strong>, NOT <strong><em></strong></em>)

  • Do not use deprecated tags or attributes, or "out of date" tags. Check the book or Google to see if a tag is deprecated or just try it and see if your page validates.

All pages that you make must have a validation link on them for both HTML and CSS. It might look something like this:

<p><a href="http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=referer">XHTML 1.0</a>,
<a href="http://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/check/referer">CSS 2.0</a></p>
item.author: (kass)

item.title: Lists
item.description:
<ul>
<li>list item</li>
<li>list item</li>
<li>list item</li>
</ul>

<li>list item</li>
<li>list item</li>
<li>list item

        <li>sublist item</li>

    </li>
  </ul>
</li>

<li>list item</li>
<li>list item</li>
</ol>

<dd>A nummy yellow fruit. OM NOM NOM NOM NOM.</dd>
<dd>Really good for tripping people.</dd>
<dd>Really good for tripping people.</dd>
<dd>Really good for tripping people.</dd>
<dt>BANANA</dt>
<dd>A nummy yellow fruit. OM NOM NOM NOM NOM.</dd>
<dt>BANANA</dt>

item.author: (kass)

item.title: Directory Linking Fun
item.description:
cats.html

<html>

<head>  
  <title>cats</title>  
</head>

<body>

<p><a href="big_cats/index.html">big cats</a></p>
<p><a href="../dogs/index.html">dogs</a></p>
<p><a href="../birds/index.html">birds</a></p>

<p><img src="cats.jpg" alt="kitties" /></p>

</body>
</html>
item.author: (kass)

item.title: HTML Basics
item.description:
<html>

<head>
<title>This is my title</title>
</head>

<body>

<h1>biggest header</h1>
<h2>next biggest header</h2>
<h3>next next biggest header</h3>
<h4>next next next biggest header</h4>
<h5>next next next next biggest header</h5>
<h6>next next next next next biggest header</h6>

<p>sldkfasj df;ksadfjsl;dkfj ;lsk fj;laskdfj 
sdfklj;woekfasj df;ksadfjsl;dkfj ;lsk fj;laskdfj 
sdfklj;woetuoe4utoiuoiuf
sdfsdfasdfsadfkfasj df;ksadfjsl;dkfj ;lsk fj;laskdfj 
sdfklj;woetuoe4utoiuoiuf
sdfsdfasdfsadftuoe4utoiuoiuf
sdfsdfasdfsadf</p>

<p>ejwlelekjrwekrjlskjdfs
sdfkjalkdflklekjrwekrjlskjdfs
sdfkjalkd <em>flk</em> lekjrwekrjlskjdfs
sdfkjalkdflklekjrwekrjlskjdfs
sdfkjalkdflklek<em><strong>jrwekr</strong></em>jlskjdfs
sdfkjalkdflkkjrwekrjlskjdfs
sdfkjalkdflks</p>


<a href="http://www.youtube.com/"><img src="pocky.jpg" alt="strawberry Pocky" /></a>

</body>

</html>
item.author: (kass)

item.title: FTP 101
item.description:
Using an FTP Program

On the TMF lab computers: Start Menu > All Programs > Networking > WinSCP SFTP.

Host name: atdpmanila.berkeley.edu
Username: First initial + last name
Password: First initial + last initial + birthdate (mmddyy)

Ex, if your name is James Bond, and your birthday is 05/16/85, your login information will be:
Username: jbond
Password: jb051685

Under "Protocol", make sure you change it to "FTP". And make sure you're putting your files in the "Sites" folder!

To FTP from home:

Download an FTP client at home to use. There are many free ones:

Mac: Fetch, Interarchy, Transmit, Cyberduck
Windows: WinSCP FTP (the program we use in the lab), AbsoluteFTP, SmartFTP, AceFTP, WS_FTP, anything else on download.com for FTP

Another way to FTP (requires no downloading!)

There's a neat website called Net2FTP that will let you FTP through your web browser. It can be a little clunky for uploading, but not having to download a program is pretty cool.
item.author: (kass)
